div.l: Yt was for nought no man his reson herd
With othis grete he was so born̄ down̄
That he was holdyn wood in al the toun̄
For eủery clerk anon right held with othir
Thei said the man was wood my leef brothir
That euery man gan laugh on his stryfe
Thus swyuyd was the carpenters wyfe
For al his kepyng and Ielousye
And absalon hath kissid hir nethir eye
And nicholay is skaldid in the toute
This tale is do god saue al this route

Of absalon and hend nicholas
Dyuers folk dyuersly said
But for the most part thei lough ⁊and plaid
Ne at the tale I saugh no man hym greue
But yif yt were only Oswald the Reeue
Be cause he was of carpenter craft
A lytel yre in his hert laft
He gan to grucche ⁊and blamyd hym a lyte
So theek qdquod he wel couth I the quyte
With bleryng of prowd mylners eye
Yif that me lyst to speke of Ribaudrye
But yk am old me lyst not pley for age
Me lyst but lyste to skippe or Rage

div.l: This white toppe wryeth myn olde yeeris
Myn hert also is moulyd as myn heer is
But I fare the frute callid as dosthe frute callidas dos an opyn ers
That ilk frute is euer lenger the wers
Til he be rotyn  right so can we not rype
We hopen ay whils that the world wil pipe
For in oure wil yt is euyr oure avayle
To haue an hore hed and a grene tayle
As hath a leek for though oᵘur myght be gon̄
Oure wil desyres foly euyr anon
Whan we may not doōn than wil we speke
Yit in oure asshis cold is fyre y reke
Foure gledis haue which þat I deuyse
Avauntyng · lyeng · angir · couetyse ·
Thise foure sparkys longyn vn to elde
Oure olde lymmys we may not wel bewelde
But wil ne shal not fayl this is sooth
And yit al weyal wey haue ik a coltissh thooth
As many a yeer as yt is passid henne
Sethyn that myn tappe of lyfe began to renne
And euer sethyn hath so the tappe y ronne
Til that almost empty is the tonne
The strem of lyfe now dropith on the thombe
And sykerly doun̄ sonkyn is the plumbe
Of wrecchidnesse that passid is ful yore
With old folk sauf dotage ther is no more
~ Whan that oure host had herd þis sermonȳng
He gan to speke as lordly as a kyng
He said what amoun̄tith al this wytte
What shal we speke al day of holy wrytte
The deuyl made a reue for to preche
Or of a souter a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thi tale and tary not the tyme
Lo here is depford and yt is half way pryme
Lo grenewich ther many a shrew is inne
Yt were al tyme thi tale to be gynne ·
Now sirs quoth this Oswald the Reue
I pray yow alle that yee yow not greue
Though I answere and somdel set his hew
For leefful is with force of a shrew
This drunkyn myllere hath vs told here
How that beguylid was a carpentere
Parauenture in scorn̄ of meof me for ik am on
And by yoᵘur leue I wil hym quyte anon
Right in his churlissh termys wil I speke
I pray god  the deuyl his necke breke
He can wel in myn eye seen a stalke
But in his owne he can not see a balke ·

At Trumpyngtoıı̄un not fer for caunbrigge
Þ̉er gos a brook and ouyr þᵗat a brigge
Vppon the whiche brook ther standis a mylle
And this is verray sooth that y yow telle
A myllere was ther dwellyng many a day
As any pecok he was prowd and gay
Pypen he couth and fisshen ⁊and nettys beete
And turne cuppis and wel wrastle and sheete
Ay by his belt he bar a long panade
And of a swerd ful trenchant was þe blade
A ioly poppere bar he in his pouche
Ther was no man for ꝑperel durst hym touche
A sheffeld twitell bar he in his hose ·
Rounde was his face and kammyssh was his nose
